Award.AwardTitle: Photonic Imaging Receiver for Ultra-wideband Radio-frequency Communications and Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
A new concept in radio frequency (RF) receivers will be developed under this program. RF receivers are a vital component in a variety of systems that are yielding transformative benefits for society. Perhaps most prominent is wireless broadband internet connectivity. Enhancing the capacity of wireless networks will accelerate the benefits of worldwide connectivity among households, schools, hospitals, businesses, and governments. The photonic imaging receiver uses optical detection and processing of RF signals to enable unprecedented capabilities, from extremely broadband wireless communications to all-weather obscurant-penetrating imaging. Conventional RF receivers are limited by the intrinsic nonlinearity of the detection process, by which multiple signals mix and generate spurious responses. The unique capability of the imaging receiver system is the use of optics to"see" upconverted RF signals much like the eye or a camera sees visible light: sources of RF energy within its field of view produce distinct spots on an image plane or camera sensor, whereupon these spots can be detected separately, minimizing intermixing. This approach affords advantages in speed, complexity, linearity, and also adds new capabilities such as real-time direction finding, tracking, and processing of multiple signal sources. The imaging receiver system will offer increased capacity in wireless networks, while also improving performance and reducing infrastructure cost. The same enabling technology will also provide benefits in transportation and search/rescue operations, allowing navigation in obscurants like fog, smoke, and sand. Likewise, security checkpoints will be able to screen persons and vehicles passively at a distance, enhancing both security and convenience. The research effort will investigate the limits and optimize the performance potential of such imaging receiver systems.

The photonic imaging receiver is a novel type of phased array receiver that uses the coherent properties of frequency upconversion in optical modulators to detect radio-frequency (RF) signals, and simple free-space optics to perform signal correlations between array elements, which are conventionally performed computationally after signals are detected and digitized. The optical upconversion process offers broad bandwidth, from UHF to millimeter-wave. Free-space optical processing enables signals coming from different sources to be spatially separated prior to detection, minimizing intermodulation and dramatically improving spur-free dynamic range (SFDR). It also provides the array gain of a phased array receiver, but with the advantage of forming all beams simultaneously. The recovery of data that has been modulated onto detected RF carriers is enabled by the use of a widely tunable optical local oscillator that is mixed with the upconverted signal on a photodiode. The foundation of the technical approach has been proven in the context of passive millimeter-wave imaging. This research program will explore the fundamental limitations of the approach in a broad and general sense, but will primarily focus on extending the utility of the approach toward ultra-wideband wireless communications, enhancing capacity by enabling spectrum reuse through spatial division multiple access. It will also investigate a novel concept in wideband systems, namely scale invariance, which seeks to replace conventional Fourier (time-frequency) domain formalism, in which the basis functions used for carrying information are continuous-wave (CW) carriers, with a new formalism based not on time-harmonic CW carriers but rather scale-invariant functions, which are naturally suited to applications with extremely broad bandwidth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

The accomplishments of this research project were in the extension of the limits and optimization of a novel photonic imaging receiver system for communications and sensing. This system is a novel type of phased array that uses the coherent properties of frequency upconversion in high-performance optical modulators to enable unprecedented capabilities, particularly by the use of free-space optics (imaging) to perform signal correlations between many array elements. This approach offers unique advantages in terms of speed, complexity, linearity, and also adds new capabilities such as real-time direction finding, tracking, and processing of multiple signal emitters simultaneously, i.e. it provides Spatial Division Multiple Access (SDMA). 

The major goals accomplished were associated with the listed tasks in the proposal, more specifically the spatial isolation of received signals, improved linearity in system response, and the implementation of a scale-invariance in a novel temporal aperture sampling scheme, that was shown to resolve frequency information along with spatial imaging of the communication signal. Specific tasks that were completed include:

  • Characterization and refinement of the architecture of a single-channel photonic link, where the linearity was improved with a simplified implementation.
  • Developed a system for characterizing the contribution to link nonlinearity arising from the photodiode response apart from the modulation transfer function.
  • Transitioned the modulator upconversion technology behind the imaging receiver, through design, simulation, and experimental fabrication, to a more manufacturable material platform, namely thin-film Lithium Niobate (TFLN).
  • Designed and demonstrated an array of fiber-coupled photodiode detectors to realize the improved IF detection scheme discussed in the previous annual report, showing efficient coupling, spatial isolation, and broad IF detection bandwidth in a practical, low-cost implementation.

 

Major Accomplishments

In accordance with the accomplishments listed above, the major aspects of the completed project are discussed in more detail below.

  • Improved Linearized Link Architecture: During this project, a novel link architecture was conceived, analyzed and experimentally validated. It offers improved linearity by using an unbalanced pair of Mach-Zehnder Interferometer (MZI) modulators, wherein the third-order intermodulation distortion (IMD3) generated by each is equal in amplitude but opposite in phase, such that when the two modulators’ outputs are combined, the intermodulation terms cancel, while the linear response is only slightly diminished, and the net result is increased SFDR. This architecture has been improved during this period by eliminating one of the two lasers required and simplifying the resulting configuration. The role of the two different laser wavelengths has been replicated using a single laser by separating it into two different polarization states. Modeling was used to verify that the simplified architecture performed as well as the original 2-laser scheme. 
  • Photodiode Nonlinearity Measurement: Nonlinearities arise in photonic links from the modulator, which is addressed by the link architecture described previously. Additional nonlinearities come from the photodetector however, and the linearized link architecture does not address these. To better understand photodetector nonlinearities, we modeled and experimentally demonstrated a three-tone nonlinearity characterization system, and used it to characterize high-performance photodiodes. 
  • Thin-film Lithium Niobate Modulators: Transitioning the imaging receiver from the level of a proven technology concept to a commercially viable reality required improving the manufacturability of key devices and components, and none is more critical than the optical modulators. To this end, we identified the TFLN material system as a promising candidate for fabricating modulators using silicon-photonics foundry-compatible processes, and have designed, fabricated, and tested initial prototype devices.
  • Broadband Fiber-coupled IF Detector Array: Extending the IF detection concept presented in the previous report, namely using lens coupled fibers in the image plane in place of bare photodetectors to improve spatial isolation, we designed and demonstrated a high-speed detector array to use in conjunction with the lens-coupled fiber array. This development allows the improved spatial isolation to be realized for all spatial beams at the same time, with greatly increased instantaneous bandwidth.
